Path of the Berserker.name: Senda del Berserker
Path of the Berserker.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.EceyH0R2456kRdtW caption=false classes="right three"]

Channel Rage into Violent Fury

Barbarians who walk the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrbBerserker0]{Path of the Berserker} direct their Rage primarily toward violence. Their path is one of untrammeled fury, and they thrill in the chaos of battle as they allow their Rage to seize and empower them.

Path of the Wild Heart.name: Senda del Corazón Salvaje
Path of the Wild Heart.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.Rk0QcsmW6g5c4XzL caption=false classes="three right"]

Walk in Community with the Animal World

Barbarians who follow the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrbWildHeart0]{Path of the Wild Heart} view themselves as kin to animals. These Barbarians learn magical means to communicate with animals, and their Rage heightens their connection to animals as it fills them with supernatural might.

Path of the World Tree.name: Senda del Árbol del Mundo
Path of the World Tree.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.Z2RPOWDkIBXRG0CQ caption=false classes="three right"]

Trace the Roots and Branches of the Multiverse

Barbarians who follow the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrbWorldTree0]{Path of the World Tree} connect with the cosmic tree Yggdrasil through their Rage. This tree grows among the Outer Planes, connecting them to each other and the Material Plane. These Barbarians draw on the tree’s magic for vitality and as a means of dimensional travel.

Path of the Zealot.name: Senda del Fanático
Path of the Zealot.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.rbUcTqEpuFZlIQiX caption=false classes="three right"]

Rage in Ecstatic Union with a God

Barbarians who walk the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrbZealot0000]{Path of the Zealot} receive boons from a god or pantheon. These Barbarians experience their Rage as an ecstatic episode of divine union that infuses them with power. They are often allies to the priests and other followers of their god or pantheon.

Barbarian.name: Bárbaro
Barbarian.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.SEwCFWmoe5wPqLWP caption=false]

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrbBarbarian0]{Barbarians} are mighty warriors who are powered by primal forces of the multiverse that manifest as a Rage. More than a mere emotion—and not limited to anger—this Rage is an incarnation of a predator’s ferocity, a storm’s fury, and a sea’s turmoil.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.TA4xDoWO2cXuWKgX caption=false classes="right three"]

Some Barbarians personify their Rage as a fierce spirit or revered forebear. Others see it as a connection to the pain and anguish of the world, as an impersonal tangle of wild magic, or as an expression of their own deepest self. For every Barbarian, their Rage is a power that fuels not just battle prowess, but also uncanny reflexes and heightened senses.

Barbarians often serve as protectors and leaders in their communities. They charge headlong into danger so those under their protection don’t have to. Their courage in the face of danger makes Barbarians perfectly suited for adventure.

Becoming a Barbarian …

As a Level 1 Character

  • Gain all the traits in the Core Barbarian Traits table.

  • Gain the Barbarian’s level 1 features, which are listed in the Barbarian Features table.

As a Multiclass Character

  • Gain the following traits from the Core Barbarian Traits table: Hit Point Die, proficiency with Martial weapons, and training with Shields.

  • Gain the Barbarian’s level 1 features, which are listed in the Barbarian Features table.
Barbarian.subclass: A Barbarian subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. The next pages present the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.GvRPKO7EAbXB7TXM]{Path of the Berserker}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.DZftqg73PEeRWY4J]{Path of the Wild Heart}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.0NPflCZJaxFKhpXu]{Path of the World Tree}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.JZkVWnkmB47BwtLi]{Path of the Zealot} subclasses.

Bard.name: Bard
Bard.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.UH2FRBZlS7owFx0R caption=false]

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.mwPJyvhdaQxLSOkX caption=false classes="right two"]

Invoking magic through music, dance, and verse, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrdBard000000]{Bards} are expert at inspiring others, soothing hurts, disheartening foes, and creating illusions. Bards believe the multiverse was spoken into existence and that remnants of its Words of Creation still resound and glimmer on every plane of existence. Bardic magic attempts to harness those words, which transcend any language.

Anything can inspire a new song or tale, so Bards are fascinated by almost everything. They become masters of many things, including performing music, working magic, and making jests.

A Bard’s life is spent traveling, gathering lore, telling stories, and living on the gratitude of audiences, much like any other entertainer. But Bards’ depth of knowledge and mastery of magic sets them apart.

Becoming a Bard …

As a Level 1 Character

  • Gain all the traits in the Core Bard Traits table.

  • Gain the Bard’s level 1 features, which are listed in the Bard Features table.

As a Multiclass Character

  • Gain the following traits from the Core Bard Traits table: Hit Point Die, proficiency in one skill of your choice, proficiency with one Musical Instrument of your choice, and training with Light armor.

  • Gain the Bard’s level 1 features, which are listed in the Bard Features table. See the multiclassing rules in chapter 2 to determine your available spell slots.
Bard.subclass: A Bard subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. The next pages present the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.PPMt7mHlvqyFQ1mw]{College of Dance}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.ysmyEb6Euh5WLuA2]{College of Glamour}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.AK8mgYdk1zOiIU0w]{College of Lore}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.iAZwiVfhgi8KdNAD]{College of Valor} subclasses.

College of Dance.name: College of Dance
College of Dance.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.RISGrIITP20DrPKj caption=false classes="three right"]

Move in Harmony with the Cosmos

Bards of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrdDance00000]{College of Dance} know that the Words of Creation can’t be contained within speech or song; the words are uttered by the movements of celestial bodies and flow through the motions of the smallest creatures. These Bards practice a way of being in harmony with the whirling cosmos that emphasizes agility, speed, and grace.

College of Glamour.name: College of Glamour
College of Glamour.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.8FZ9RIiHgj7UPntB caption=false classes="three right"]

Weave Beguiling Fey Magic

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrdGlamour000]{College of Glamour} traces its origins to the beguiling magic of the Feywild. Bards who study this magic weave threads of beauty and terror into their songs and stories, and the mightiest among them can cloak themselves in otherworldly majesty. Their performances stir up wistful longing for forgotten innocence, evoke unconscious memories of long-held fears, and tug at the emotions of even the most hard-hearted listeners.

College of Lore.name: College of Lore
College of Lore.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.rKcbuxF24YtAkfrB caption=false classes="three right"]

Plumb the Depths of Magical Knowledge

Bards of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrdLore000000]{College of Lore} collect spells and secrets from diverse sources, such as scholarly tomes, mystical rites, and peasant tales. The college’s members gather in libraries and universities to share their lore with one another. They also meet at festivals or affairs of state, where they can expose corruption, unravel lies, and poke fun at self-important figures of authority.

College of Valor.name: College of Valor
College of Valor.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.Ddbv0hTmdZCJ7N7u caption=false classes="three right"]

Sing the Deeds of Ancient Heroes

Bards of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrdValor00000]{College of Valor} are daring storytellers whose tales preserve the memory of the great heroes of the past. These Bards sing the deeds of the mighty in vaulted halls or to crowds gathered around great bonfires. They travel to witness great events firsthand and to ensure that the memory of these events doesn’t pass away. With their songs, they inspire new generations to reach the same heights of accomplishment as the heroes of old.

1.1.2.text:
Feature Enhancements

  • Added links to Class starting equipment on the Description and not just in the Details tab. [#738]

  • Added a damage activity to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbrgrFoeSlayer0]{Foe Slayer} for the increased damage. [#730]

  • Added damage to the Explosive Rune activity on @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplGlyphofWar]{Glyph of Warding}. [#726]

  • Made the embedded table in the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplReincarnat]{Reincarnate} spell rollable. [#719]

  • Added Conjured Elemental actors for each element and linked them in their spell. [#711]

  • Removed a number of unnecessary enrichers across a few spells in favor of activities. [#706]

  • Added a color gradient for Spell folders for easier distinction. [#704]

  • Added lookup enrichers for a few scale values. [#700]

  • Added references for Weapon Masteries which will now appear when making an attack with an Item that has a Mastery. [#697]

  • Added an Unarmed Strike Item for Monks and Barbarians. [#691]

  • Embedded additional imagery throughout class and subclass pages.

Bug Fixes

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.origins.Item.phbspAasimar0000]{Aasimar} now includes an option for selecting between Small and Medium size. [#739]

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbbrbRageOfTheG]{Rage of the Gods} now sets Hover on your character and the Active Effect includes an icon. [#737]

  • Fixed @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplBane000000]{Bane}'s duration. [#736]

  • Cantrips are now all labeled as Always Prepared. [#735]

  • Fixed a few instances of advancements that granted proficiencies to multiclassed characters when they shouldn't. [#734]

  • Replaceable features should now all be correctly flagged. [#732]

  • Battlemaster now uses the correct formula for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbftrCombatSupe]{Combat Superiority}. [#728]

  • Removed extraneous text from @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplCommune000]{Commune}. [#727]

  • Removed extraneous text in the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplInflictWou]{Inflict Wounds} spell. [#725]

  • Corrected the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplSlow000000]{Slow} spell's inline roll to correctly reflect a 25% chance. [#724]

  • Removed redundant spell information from @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplCordonofAr]{Cordon of Arrows}. [#723]

  • Removed extraneous text in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplDisguiseSe]{Disguise Self}. [#721]

  • Improved the functionality of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplDispelEvil]{Dispel Evil and Good} spell with additional activities. [#720]

  • Removed duplicated activity in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplArcaneVigo]{Arcane Vigor}. [#718]

  • The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnkMonk000000]{Monk} class now displays the Focus Point column. [#717]

  • Integrated changes from the official errata. [#714]

  • Improved the functionality of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.feats.Item.phbftHealer00000]{Healer} feat and removed incorrect enrichers. [#713]

  • Resolved issue with Soulknife die scale and added a couple of Active Effect icons. [#712]

  • Removed references to optional Tasha's features in the example Bard Actor. [#709]

  • Corrected invalid formulas in some features. [#705]

  • Players now have access to the Equipment compendium pack. [#703]

  • Removed duplicate appearance of the Dragonborn image in the Equipment journal and some repeated text. [#702]

  • Corrected some Eldritch Invocation level requirements. [#699]

  • Fixed a typo in the Bardic Inspiration lookup enricher. [#698]

  • Added a scale value for the number of Weapon Masteries Known by Fighters. [#694]

  • Fixed a typo in the Paladin's @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbpdnChannelDiv]{Channel Divinity} description. [#692]

  • Added Unarmed Strike with necessary modifications to Barbarian and Monk advancement. Other characters can utilize the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbUnarmedStrike]{Unarmed Strike} weapon.

  • Removed unused Limited Use from @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbrgeSneakAttac]{Sneak Attack}. [#689]

  • Corrected Rage's scaling value and recreated the example @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbprgBarbarian0]{Barbarian}. [#688]

  • Fixed the damage type in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplEldritchBl]{Eldritch Blast}. [#687]

  • Added missing damage types to Dragonborn's @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.origins.Item.phbsptBreathWeap]{Breath Weapon} and Resistances choices. [#684]

  • Added link to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagAlchemistsF]{Alchemist's Fire}. [#683]

  • Corrected Deafened condition in the Overview page of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbConditions000]{Conditions} journal. [#682]

  • Removed broken reference. [#681]

  • Removed undesired shadow spot in Warrior of the Open Hand artwork. [#680]

  • Fixed issue with @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbinvPactBlade0]{Pact of the Blade} enchantment. [#679]

  • Corrected art handout for Tiefling Types to correctly identify the Infernal Tiefling. [#678]

Additional Fixes from Discord Reports:

  • Fixed an issue in the Dim Light explanation.

  • Fixed an issue where two names in the first social example were not highlighted correctly.

  • Fixed missing link to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagAlchemistsF]{Alchemist's Fire} in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbtulAlchemists]{Alchemist's Supplies}.

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplTongues000]{Tongues} now targets 1 creature rather than 1 enemy.

  • Added a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbSorcerer00000.JournalEntryPage.XSkwrMRz9FDvovd1]{Metamagic Options} page to the Sorcerer's journal.

  • Increased the visibility of the "Replacing Spellbooks" callout by placing it in the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbWizard0000000.JournalEntryPage.g7cMRWzsgAsEF7zC]{Wizard}'s journal page and not just the class Item.

  • Added damage type to the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplVitriolicS]{Vitriolic Sphere}.

  • Removed unnecessary inline rolls.

  • Resolved some issues with multiclass characters being granted skill proficiencies.

1.2.0.text:
Feature Enhancements

  • Added templates for Detect Magic, Detect Thoughts, Detect Poison and Disease, and Detect Evil and Good. They are configured to not prompt you to place the template on cast to reduce visual noise but the chat card will allow placing it. Their Active Effects have also been updated for more clarity. [#764]
  • Added an Unarmed Strike item as an advancement grant to the College of Dance subclass which can be used in place of the activity on the Dazzling Footwork feature. [#759]

Bug Fixes

  • Added Musket and Pistol as Base Weapon options. [#753]
  • The Net now includes a Save activity and an inline check for escaping the net. [#763]
  • Added spell progression formula for Eldritch Knight. [#761]
  • The Bard no longer grants the multiclass skill proficiency to the original class. [#760]
  • Added missing text to the Wizard's "Expanding and Replacing a Spellbook" callout. [#757]
  • Removed "Bludgeoning" from the Martial Arts' Monk Attack activity. [#755]
  • Corrected the amount of HP granted to the Primal Companion when they're summoned to ensure the Beast of the Sky gets the correct value. [#754]
  • Warlock subclass spells are all added as "Pact Magic" now. [#750]
  • The Druid class now adds Druidic as a language. [#747]
  • Fixed link issue with Alchemist's Fire. [#748]
  • The "Magician" Druid feature now modifies the correct scale value. [#746]
  • Added Darkvision to the Skeleton. [#745]
  • Corrected Stunning Strike to use Wisdom. [#744]
  • Eldritch Invocations are now all granted at the appropriate levels. [#743]
  • Fixed typo in the Agonizing Blast invocation. [#742]
  • Fixed a typo in the Rage feature's lookup value. [#769]
  • The Aasimar's Healing Hands feature now correctly consumes item uses instead of activity uses. [#770]
  • Divine Smite now allows critical damage. [#771]

Miscellaneous Unreported Issues/Feature Enhancements

  • [BUG] Rebuilt all example Actors with the latest version of their class.
  • [BUG] Added damage type to Monk's Unarmed Strike.
  • [ENHANCEMENT] Set the granted Misty Step with free uses from the Archfey Patron to be "At-Will" to distinguish it from the standard version which consumes spell slots.

Features

Bug Fixes

  • Added the correct art for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbginGiantWasp0]{Giant Wasp}. [#910]

  • Added icons to the Active Effects in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbdrdNaturesWar]{Nature's Ward}. [#914]

  • Added Icon to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbftrImprovedCr]{Improved Critical} activity; Corrected Typo in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbftrTacticalMa]{Tactical Master}. [#915]

  • Updated "references.mjs" to point ability references to the correct compendium page in PHB. Also updated the compendium reference for &Reference[reactioncasting]. With respect to the reporter's description in the issue, the spell describes two, mutually exclusive activities. One is a bonus action and the other is a free action that occurs after the bonus action. [#934]

  • The token subject image for the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbprgDruid00000]{Druid} example character to the correct path. [#937]

  • Set attack ability to DEX for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbudsGhostlySpi]{Ghostly Spirit}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbudsPutridSpir]{Putrid Spirit}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbudsSkeletalSp]{Skeletal Spirit}.   • Updated DC formula to "8 + @abilities.str.mod + @prof" in three instances (Barbarian, Bard, Monk) of Unarmed Strike's Grapple/Shove activity (corrects typo). [#955]

  • Added a link to Dancing Lights in the Elven Lineages table in the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbSpeciesDescri.JournalEntryPage.h9oGyt2Wh9mp0xbg]{Elf} species description.

  • Corrected typo in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcWardingFla]{Warding Flare}'s description.

  • Added @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplBless00000]{Bless} to the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcLifeDomain]{Life Domain} cleric's level 3 spells.

1.4.0.text:
Get Updated Items From Your Class, Subclass, Species, and Backgrounds

If one or more of the items/features granted to you by your class, subclass, species, or background were updated and you'd like to get the new version follow these steps:

  1. Back up your Actor by making a copy of it in the World by right clicking on the Actor in the sidebar and selecting "Duplicate".

  2. Review the list of updated items in this changelog for items that are granted by your Class, Subclass, Species, or Background to determine what needs to be replaced.

  3. Right click on the Class/Subclass/Species/Background that granted you the item and select "Edit".

  4. Go to the item's "Advancement" tab.

  5. Find the level that granted the item in the Advancement list.

  6. Delete the old item from your character sheet.

  7. In the Advancement list click on the cog icon in the top right of the level that granted it to re-run the advancement which will grant you the updated feature.

Replace Your Entire Class, Subclass, Species, or Background

If there were changes to your Class, Subclass, Species, or Background (not just the items/features that they grant you as you level up) that you would like to have you can follow these steps:

  1. Back up your Actor by making a copy of it in the World by right clicking on the Actor in the sidebar and selecting "Duplicate".

  2. Right click on the Class, Subclass, Species, or Background item and delete it.

  3. In the window that pops up leave the "Remove advancement changes" box checked and press the "Delete" button. This will remove all of the items/features granted to you by that item.

  4. Add your Class, Subclass, Species, or Background back to your sheet. You can then re-level your character. Refer to your back up Actor if you would like to ensure the choices are all the same.

Feature Enhancements

  • Improved styling and scoping rules for better appearance and less spillover styling.

  • Updated Epic Boon Feats and General Feats to support ASIs. [#973, #716]

  • Consolidated activities in the Battle Master maneuvers: @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnvDisarmingA]{Disarming Attack}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnvTripAttack]{Trip Attack}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnvPushingAtt]{Pushing Attack}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnvMenacingAt]{Menacing Attack}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnvGoadingAtt]{Goading Attack}. [#922]

  • Re-ordered the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplSearingSmi]{Searing Smite} spell's activities. [#888]

  • Updated the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbmobConstricto]{Constrictor Snake} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbmobVenomousSn]{Venomous Snake} to use new artwork that became available in the 2024 Monster Manual. [#701]

  • Removed the second activity from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplSlow000000]{Slow} spell as the inline roll in the description covers its use.

Bug Fixes

  • Added the correct art for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbginGiantWasp0]{Giant Wasp}. [#910]

  • Added icons to the Active Effects in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbdrdNaturesWar]{Nature's Ward}. [#914]

  • Added Icon to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbftrImprovedCr]{Improved Critical} activity; Corrected Typo in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbftrTacticalMa]{Tactical Master}. [#915]

  • Updated "references.mjs" to point ability references to the correct compendium page in PHB. Also updated the compendium reference for &Reference[reactioncasting]. Note that the syntax for the reference to Conjuration magic is &Reference[spellSchool=con] (spellSchool=con) since "con" is also used to reference Constitution. [#920]

  • Updated @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.feats.Item.phbftHealer00000]{Healer} Feat, clarifying the title of the Battle Medic activities, and edited activities so they will reroll a result of 1 in the background. [#932, #923]

  • Added missing condition Active Effect to Save vs. Push activity in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplThunderous]{Thunderous Smite} spell. With respect to the reporter's description in the issue, the spell describes two, mutually exclusive activities. One is a bonus action and the other is a free action that occurs after the bonus action. [#934]

  • The token subject image for the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbprgDruid00000]{Druid} example character to the correct path. [#937]

  • Set attack ability to DEX for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbudsGhostlySpi]{Ghostly Spirit}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbudsPutridSpir]{Putrid Spirit}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbudsSkeletalSp]{Skeletal Spirit}. [#941]

  • Corrected @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplConjureFey]{Conjure Fey} summon activity Bonus Attack Damage formula. [#942]

  • Updated @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbrgeSneakAttac]{Sneak Attack} feature to allow for Crit damage. [#944]

  • Added damage type to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplHeatMetal0]{Heat Metal} where it was missing in the activities. [#949]

  • Updated "references.mjs" to point the reference for Push weapons mastery. Note that the syntax for the reference is &Reference[weaponMastery=push] (weaponMastery=push) since the word "push" is used in other references. [#953]

  • Updated modifier for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbwzdEmpoweredE]{Empowered Evocation} to use "@abilities.int.mod" rather than "@abilities.cha.mod". [#954]

  • Updated DC formula to "8 + @abilities.str.mod + @prof" in three instances (Barbarian, Bard, Monk) of Unarmed Strike's Grapple/Shove activity (corrects typo). [#955]

  • In advancement for the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.origins.Item.phbspForestGnome]{Forest Gnome} Species, Minor Illusion and Speak with Animals are split into separate advancement items so a casting limit ("@prof") is applied to the spell and not the cantrip. [#956]

  • Updated @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.origins.Item.phbbgAcolyte0000]{Acolyte} equipment and compendium links to reference PHB 2024 items (parchment, added holy symbol). [#959]

  • Updated @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.feats.Item.phbftTavernBrawl]{Tavern Brawler} Feat damage roll formula to "1d4r1 + @abilities.str.mod". [#964]

  • Standardized identifier in Prepared Spells advancement items to "max-prepared" for all spellcasting classes and subclasses. [#965]

  • Updated the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbmnvRally00000]{Rally} maneuver feature's healing formula to "@scale.battle-master.superiority.die + (floor(@classes.fighter.levels/2))". [#968]

  • Updated @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.feats.Item.phbftAlert000000]{Alert} feat to use the "flags.dnd5e.initiativeAlert" attribute. [#970]

  • Updated @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbwlkHealingLig]{Healing Light} activity's Max Scaling formula to "clamp(@abilities.cha.mod, 1, @item.uses.value)". [#987]

  • Updated all documents to utilize the new "spell.mod.dc" and "spell.mod" values. [#967]

  • Added a link to Dancing Lights in the Elven Lineages table in the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbSpeciesDescri.JournalEntryPage.h9oGyt2Wh9mp0xbg]{Elf} species description.

  • Added a link to @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbSpells0000000.JournalEntryPage.YSB1QtxZW2BI9f4Y#casting-without-slots]{Casting without Slots} to the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbwzdRitualAdep]{Ritual Adept} feature.

  • Added Freedom of Movement to the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbSpells0000000.JournalEntryPage.wwia6Wwo4BgE9GSI]{Bard spell list}.

  • Corrected typo in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcWardingFla]{Warding Flare}'s description.

  • Added @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplBless00000]{Bless} to the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcLifeDomain]{Life Domain} cleric's level 3 spells.

  • The Abjurer's @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbwzdArcaneWard]{Arcane Ward} now uses the correct formulas.

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplFeignDeath]{Feign Death}'s Active Effect no longer automatically applies when the spell is added to your sheet.

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.actors.Actor.phbsplTinyDancin]{Dancing Light (Tiny)} now has the correct token scaling.

  • The Control Water and Ice Storm spells are now granted as "Always Prepared" for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbdrdCirsea0000]{Circle of the Sea} druids.

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.origins.Item.phbspDrow0000000]{Elf, Drow}'s Darkness trait is now correctly granted a free use per Long Rest.

  • The Starting Equipment for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbdrdDruid00000]{Druid}s, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbscrSorcerer00]{Sorcerer}s, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbwlkWarlock000]{Warlock}s, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbwzdWizard0000]{Wizard}s now includes their specific focus rather than any focus of their given type.

  • Added an Active Effect for @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplBlur000000]{Blur} to make it easier to track.

  • Removed some redundant condition references which prevented the apply condition button from appearing.

  • Standardized the naming of activities across a variety of spells.

  • Implemented the details of @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagAlchemistsF]{Alchemist's Fire}.

2.0.0.text:
Get Updated Items From Your Class, Subclass, Species, and Backgrounds

If one or more of the items/features granted to you by your class, subclass, species, or background were updated and you'd like to get the new version follow these steps:

  1. Back up your Actor by making a copy of it in the World by right clicking on the Actor in the sidebar and selecting "Duplicate".

  2. Review the list of updated items in this changelog for items that are granted by your Class, Subclass, Species, or Background to determine what needs to be replaced.

  3. Right click on the Class/Subclass/Species/Background that granted you the item and select "Edit".

  4. Go to the item's "Advancement" tab.

  5. Find the level that granted the item in the Advancement list.

  6. Delete the old item from your character sheet.

  7. In the Advancement list click on the cog icon in the top right of the level that granted it to re-run the advancement which will grant you the updated feature.

Replace Your Entire Class, Subclass, Species, or Background

If there were changes to your Class, Subclass, Species, or Background (not just the items/features that they grant you as you level up) that you would like to have you can follow these steps:

  1. Back up your Actor by making a copy of it in the World by right clicking on the Actor in the sidebar and selecting "Duplicate".

  2. Right click on the Class, Subclass, Species, or Background item and delete it.

  3. In the window that pops up leave the "Remove advancement changes" box checked and press the "Delete" button. This will remove all of the items/features granted to you by that item.

  4. Add your Class, Subclass, Species, or Background back to your sheet. You can then re-level your character. Refer to your back up Actor if you would like to ensure the choices are all the same.

Features and Enhancements

AppV2 Journals

  • Updates module journals to system v2 apps with light/dark mode support.
  • Moves module navigation flags to system versions.
  • ToC now shows the following entries: D20 tests, Social Interaction, Exploration, Combat, Damage and Healing, Conditions. #1142
  • ToC now hides the following pages: Weapon Properties, Mastery Properties.
  • Adds missing bidirectional nav link for "Crafting Equipment" to "Spells".
  • Re-orders and corrects ToC entries to match print ordering. #1107
  • Links subclass intros to subclass pages instead of subclass Item links. #1167

Spell lists for each subclass. #1258

  • Adds subclass specific spell lists (from always prepped spell subclass features) for: Cleric, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Rogue, Sorcerer, and Warlock.

Monk class and subclass features. #1179, #1180, #1181, #1182, #1086

  • Martial Arts: Weapon enchantment changes.

    • Adds finesse (to grab str or dex as needed).
    • Overrides the normal/one-hand damage to be a formula = monk.die + mod.
    • Removes "Monk Attack" rider activity (the above changes provide the functionality implicitly).

  • Elemental Attunement: Changed "Elemental Attunement" utility activity into a self-enchanting activity.

    • Correctly consumes "Focus Point" item uses on activation.
    • Activation set to "start of turn" to provide a combat prompt for its use.
    • Enchantment provides activities for both the modified damage types of an unarmed strike and the resulting push/pull save.
    • Enchantment also modifies its own activity name to "End Attunement" and removes activation and consumption costs.
  • Unarmed Strike class item given description linking to "Martial Arts".
  • Adds Wisdom modifier to Wholeness of Body. #1151.

Refactor of Cleric "Channel Divinity" class feature.

  • Changed Turn Undead activity to a Save. #1166.
  • Added scale value to track number of "Divine Spark" dice to roll and integrated into corresponding Heal and Save activities. #1100

Warlock's Eldritch Invocations

  • The following invocations have been marked 'repeatable': Agonizing blast, Eldritch spear, Lessons of the first ones, and Repelling blast. #1025.
  • The following invocations have been refactored to make use of Cast activities: Armor of Shadows, Ascendant Step, Gift of the Depths, Mask of Many Faces, Master of Myriad Forms, Misty Visions, One with Shadows, Otherworldly Leap, Visions of Distant Realms, and Whispers of the Grave. #1066
  • Updates "Lessons of the First Ones" to make use of Item Choice advancements for Origin Feat selection.
  • Updates "Agonizing Blast" to include the Charisma mod damage bonus to enchanted spells. #1024
  • Corrects "Pact of the Chain" activities to not consume spell slots. #1109

Improvised Weapons

  • Adds "Improvised Weapon" to Equipment compendium. #1052

Dragonborn Species Advancement

  • The damage resistance and single item grant Draconic Ancestry granted at "Any Level" (level 1) has been refactored into five separate Breath Weapons, each granting their specific damage resistance and damage scale value via Advancements. #1111

Illusion Spells and Study Activities. #821

  • Adds "Study" activities for Investigation checks related to illusions to the following spells: Disguise Self, Silent Image, Seeming, Project Image, Programmed Illusion, Phantasmal Force, Minor Illusion, Major Image, and Hallucinatory Terrain.

Primal Companion Upgrades and Corrections #1204.

  • Converts all Primal Companion "Beast's Strike" features to natural weapons.
  • Corrects Beast of the Sky's attack ability to use default modifier for natural weapons.

  • Removes Force damage option from all Beast's Strikes.

    • "Exceptional Training" now includes an enchantment intended to apply to the Strikes which adds "Force" as a damage option.
  • Corrects "Primal Companion" feature to provide a heal for the current summon, rather than summoning a new one.
  • Additionally, the "Summon Companion" activity is configured to occur at the end of a Long Rest to be shown as a reminder.

Class Advancements, Epic Boons, and Capstone Features #1280

  • Modifies all level 19 class advancements related to Epic Boons to take advantage of the system's specific handling at that level (via ASI advancement).

  • Corrects level 20 (capstone) features granting ability score increases to avoid erroneous "Epic Boon" entry in the class summary table.

    • Affected classes: Barbarian and Monk

Fixes

Unarmed Strikes #1181.

  • Corrects normal Unarmed Strike save activity to use Strength as its DC.
  • Simplifies normal and Monk Unarmed Strike and gives condition icons to the AEs.
  • Corrects monk Unarmed Strike grapple/shove save to use either str or dex for its DC.
  • Differentiates various "Unarmed Strike" item variants with unique icons and clarified descriptions. #1178
  • Replaces Barbarian specific unarmed strike (granted via advancement) with the "general" unarmed strike.

Hex and Hunter's Mark

  • Both spell damage activities set to allow critical damage. #1192.
  • Adds bonus action activity (no slot consumption) for moving the mark/hex.
  • Adds ability check disadvantage changes to Hex AEs.
  • Removes erroneous "1 round" duration on Hex AEs. #1063
  • Corrects application of Hunter's Mark AEs from its activities. #1062

Parry (Maneuver) #1225.

  • Added max of str/dex to healing formula (per Issue).
  • Clarified that the healing activity retroactively restores (rather than "reduces") damage.

War Bond #1242.

  • Allow magical items for Enchantment activity.
  • Changes activation cost to 'End of Short Rest' with a note of "or 1hr"
  • Adds icon to enchantment.
  • Updates item details for better accuracy.

Inspiring Leader note clarification #958.

  • Indicates user should delete the activity associated with the unaffected score once the ASI is decided.
  • Changes activation cost to "short rest" as a reminder.

Arcane Ward and Projected Ward

  • Corrects Projected Ward's max scaling consumption formula. #1149
  • Simplifies usage and consumption formulas for Arcane Ward.
  • Arcane Ward is now initially granted with zero remaining uses (e.g. 0 HP) and resets to zero at the end of a Long Rest.

Clarifies "Slow" (Spell) inline cast success roll #1020.

Corrects Barbarian starting equipment grouping #1021.

  • Removes extraneous outer grouping.

Corrects "Focus (Varies)" item grant for Acolyte background #1023.

  • Changes "generic" focus item to "any focus item" choice.

Corrects and Upgrades Warrior of the Gods #1045.

  • Moves die pool scale value to feature item as scale value advancement.
  • Changes scale value to only represent die count as the die size is static.
  • Corrects usage scaling to a maximum of remaining uses (@item.uses.value).

Synaptic Static damage roll

  • Corrects damage roll denomination from d8 to d6.

Lightning Arrow damage type #1047.

  • Sets secondary damage activity to have lightning damage type.

Corrects Protection Fighting style effect #1262

  • Removes "apply to actor" setting for indicator AE.

Ammunition container capacity settings #1252

  • Quiver and Crossbow Bolt Case set to hold 20 "items".

Adds missing "Concentration" component to spells #1247

  • Affected spells: Hypnotic Pattern and Otiluke's Resilient Sphere.

Removes invalid spell UUID entries (hidden in UI) from certain spell lists #1134

  • Affected spell lists: Bard and Wizard.

Improvements to Shillelagh enchantments #1119

  • Damage die changes now also applied to the weapon's versatile damage for correct two-handed attack and damage rolls.

Class starting equipment corrections #1098

  • Druid class granted "Wooden Staff" as opposed to "Staff" (arcane focus).
  • Ranger class explicitly granted "Sprig of Mistletoe" as opposed to "Any Druidic Focus".

Bigby's Hand — Clenched Fist correction #1097

  • Corrects attack damage formula (offsets by -5 instead of -8).

Druid's Primal Order item choice active effects clarified #1088

  • Warden: Assigns missing icon and renamed active effect.
  • Magician: Renames active effect.

Clarifies intention of lineage/legacy species trait items #1067

  • Affects Elven Lineage, Gnomish Lineage, and Fiendish Legacy items only.
  • Given "book" icon and requirement's field indicating "For Reference Only".

Corrects AE name for "Tactical Master" #1058

  • From "Tactial Master" to "Tactical Master".

Corrects Wrath of the Sea (Druid) #1112

  • Adds AE to renamed "Manifest Ocean Spray" (formerly "Save") activity with 10-minute duration.
  • Defaults "Bonus Action Save" activity to not place a measured template.

Adjustments to spells with ongoing effects #1050

  • To help unify spell-usage patterns, the following spells have had their "initial cast" and "per turn save" type activities compressed into a single "Cast and Save" activity. When casting a spell that deals damage or otherwise affects creatures for an non-instantaneous duration, it is recommend to "pop out" the spell card when initially cast (right click the card -> Pop Out Message).

    • Spirit Guardians, Incendiary Cloud, Cloudkill, Stinking Cloud, Call Lightning, Wall of Fire

Corrects "Phantasmal Killer" spell #1113

  • Properly sets the saving throw's challenge ability to Wisdom.

  • Upgrades "Fears Manifested" AE to include disadvantage on ability checks.

    • Note: Attack roll disadvantage is not automated.

Corrects and upgrades Champion's "Survivor" feature

  • Adds Death Saving Throw advantage to renamed "Defy Death" AE. #1116
  • Properly adds Con modifier to healing formula of "Heroic Rally".

Corrects "Criminal" (Origin) ASI advancement hint #1144

  • Erroneously worded hint indicating a Charisma increase changed to Intelligence. No functional changes to this Advancement.

Corrects "Feign Death" (spell) active effect. #1156

  • Removes "apply to actor" as it can be cast on any willing creature.

"Halfling Nimbleness" (Halfling) grants associated special trait #1250

  • Adds Active Effect granting this special trait flag.

"Resourceful" (Origin feat) clarifications

  • Activity set to activate at the end of a Long Rest as a reminder.
  • Adds note to clarify that inspiration is not automatically granted to the Actor.

Spell and Feature targeting corrections #1251

  • The following items have been updated to target "Self" and/or had their self-applied effects marked as "Apply to Actor" for player self-application.

    • Spells: Augury, Locate Object, Commune, Tree Stride, Magic Jar, Mislead, Goodberry, Disguise Self, Comprehend Languages, Divine Favor, Fount of Moonlight, Expeditious Retreat, False Life, Blur, Blink, Contact Other Plane, Fire Shield, Arcane Vigor, Mirror Image, Speak with Animals
    • Features: Evasive Footwork, Guarded Mind, Living Legend, Bastion of Law, Unbreakable Majesty, Rage of the Wilds

Journal Content and Styling Corrections

  • "Miniatures and Battle Grid" topic line in "What You Need" is now correctly bolded. #1103
  • Corrects "Pact Blade/Tome/Chain" invocation option titles to proper "X of the Y" form. #1090
  • "Deafened" condition link in "Conditions" journal (Overview) now correctly points to relevant condition instead of Exhaustion. #1083
  • Replaces overlapping PHB provided references with those found in SRD 5.2 (Modern Content). #1221
  • Corrects erroneous table styling applied to embedded statblock ability scores.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.aM4O5ms7ShU53CaZ caption=false]

Character class provides a character’s most exciting capabilities. This chapter offers twelve classes, each of which contains four subclasses—all summarized below.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.z2RxKBICH6e6SkUT]{Barbarian}. Storm with Rage, and wade into hand-to-hand combat. Then follow the Path of the …

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.GvRPKO7EAbXB7TXM]{Berserker} to unleash raw violence.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.DZftqg73PEeRWY4J]{Wild Heart} to manifest kinship with animals.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.0NPflCZJaxFKhpXu]{World Tree} to tap into cosmic vitality.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBarbarian0000.JournalEntryPage.JZkVWnkmB47BwtLi]{Zealot} to rage in union with a god.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.V8pqIWlaL9GhY61t]{Bard}. Perform spells that inspire and heal allies or beguile foes. Then join the College of …

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.PPMt7mHlvqyFQ1mw]{Dance} to harness agility in battle.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.ysmyEb6Euh5WLuA2]{Glamour} to weave beguiling Feywild magic.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.AK8mgYdk1zOiIU0w]{Lore} to collect knowledge and magical secrets.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBard000000000.JournalEntryPage.iAZwiVfhgi8KdNAD]{Valor} to wield weapons with spells.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.acPyA6A4DQBSnuZB]{Cleric}. Invoke divine magic to heal, bolster, and smite. Then harness the …

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.aGYpgynZ3nkBCPaT]{Life Domain} to be a master of healing.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.ChPhvB57FhM48ECO]{Light Domain} to wield searing, warding light.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.G4wCgd6yslvpvKyN]{Trickery Domain} to bedevil foes with mischief.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.r6CueEIytzMeRwwo]{War Domain} to inspire valor and chastise foes.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbDruid00000000.JournalEntryPage.UCOh3zlvGxyk5jLr]{Druid}. Channel nature magic to heal, shape-shift, and control the elements. Then join the Circle of the …

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbDruid00000000.JournalEntryPage.Ysgeru1iCA7CCe3x]{Land} to draw on the magic of the environment.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbDruid00000000.JournalEntryPage.HEtjvqXrKrZNyl8x]{Moon} to adopt powerful animal forms.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbDruid00000000.JournalEntryPage.S1X2oB04w8E9Zo30]{Sea} to channel tides and storms.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbDruid00000000.JournalEntryPage.QaSOPbllchjZ0UUG]{Stars} to gain powers in a starry form.

Overview.name: Overview
Overview.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh4ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.2tRHWrt4zwY6tqoD]

This chapter describes the two components of an adventurer’s origin: background and species. Together, these elements suggest your character’s early experience and family origin before taking up the adventuring life and learning the capabilities of a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCharacterClas.JournalEntryPage.jlSMyO89AI0ZtQjd]{class}.

Origin Components

Each part of your character’s origin reflects facets of your character, their life, and the circumstances that started them on the path to adventure.

If you choose a background or a species from an older book, see the sidebar @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCreatingAChar.JournalEntryPage.9o8NbQ1Ph2xCxlQh#backgrounds-and-species-from-older-books]{Backgrounds and Species from Older Books} in chapter 2 for how to use them with the options here.

Character Backgrounds.name: Character Backgrounds
Character Backgrounds.text:
Your character’s background is a collection of characteristics that represent the place and occupation that were most formative before your character embarked on a life of adventure.

Each background includes a brief narrative of what your character’s past might have been like. Alter the details of this narrative however you like.

Explore available @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbBackgroundDes.JournalEntryPage.lXqvtf9mIp8RYjFr]{backgrounds}.

Parts of a Background

A background includes the following parts.

Ability Scores. A background lists three of your character’s ability scores. Increase one by 2 and another one by 1, or increase all three by 1. None of these increases can raise a score above 20.

Feat. A background gives your character a specified Origin feat (described in chapter 5).

Skill Proficiencies. A background gives your character proficiency in two specified skills.

Tool Proficiency. Each background gives a character proficiency with one tool—either a specific tool or one chosen from the Artisan’s Tools category. Tools are detailed in chapter 6.

Equipment. Each background offers a choice between a package of equipment and 50 GP.

Character Species.name: Character Species
Character Species.text:
When you choose your character’s species, you determine whether your character is a human or a member of a fantastical species, such as dragonborn or gnome.

The peoples of the D&D multiverse hail from different worlds and include many kinds of sapient life forms. A player character’s species is the set of game traits that an adventurer gains from being one of those life forms.

Some species can trace their origin to a single world, plane of existence, or god, while other species first appeared in multiple realms at once. Whatever a species’ genesis, its members have spread across the multiverse and contribute to many different cultures.

Members of most species live for about 80 years, with exceptions noted in the text about the species in this chapter. Regardless of life span, members of all species reach physical maturity at about the same age. Your character can be any age that isn’t beyond their species’ normal life span.

Explore Available @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbSpeciesDescri.JournalEntryPage.7iLsgz6RUQJVpUsH]{Species}.

Parts of a Species

A species includes the following parts.

Creature Type. A character’s species determines the character’s creature type, which is described in the rules glossary. Every species in this chapter is Humanoid; playable non-Humanoid species appear in other D&D books.

Size. Your character’s species determines the character’s size. Individuals within a species cover a wide range of heights, and some species include such diversity of size that you can choose whether your character is Small or Medium.

Speed. Your character’s species determines the character’s Speed.

Special Traits. Each species gives a character special traits—unique characteristics based on the species’ physiology or magical nature. When you choose a species, your character gets all the special traits listed for it. Some traits involve making a choice from a handful of options.

Cleric.name: Cleric
Cleric.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.UuvlT8YBqkDMyj9R caption=false]

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcCleric0000]{Clerics} draw power from the realms of the gods and harness it to work miracles. Blessed by a deity, a pantheon, or another immortal entity, a Cleric can reach out to the divine magic of the Outer Planes—where gods dwell—and channel it to bolster people and battle foes.

Because their power is a divine gift, Clerics typically associate themselves with temples dedicated to the deity or other immortal force that unlocked their magic. Harnessing divine magic doesn’t rely on specific training, yet Clerics might learn prayers and rites that help them draw on power from the Outer Planes.

Not every member of a temple or shrine is a Cleric. Some priests are called to a simple life of temple service, carrying out their devotion through prayer and rituals, not through magic. Many mortals claim to speak for the gods, but few can marshal the power of those gods the way a Cleric can.

Becoming a Cleric …

As a Level 1 Character

Gain all the traits in the Core Cleric Traits table.

  • Gain the Cleric’s level 1 features, which are listed in the Cleric Features table.

As a Multiclass Character

  • Gain the following traits from the Core Cleric Traits table: Hit Point Die and training with Light and Medium armor and Shields.

  • Gain the Cleric’s level 1 features, which are listed in the Cleric Features table. See the multiclassing rules in chapter 2 to determine your available spell slots.
Cleric.subclass:
A Cleric subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. The next pages present the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.aGYpgynZ3nkBCPaT]{Life Domain}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.ChPhvB57FhM48ECO]{Light Domain}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.G4wCgd6yslvpvKyN]{Trickery Domain}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCleric0000000.JournalEntryPage.r6CueEIytzMeRwwo]{War Domain} subclasses.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.iYYIz9iJWpRfYyFF caption=false]

Life Domain.name: Life Domain
Life Domain.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.ni0tD2OhmzJVVjxZ caption=false classes="three right"]

Soothe the Hurts of the World

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcLifeDomain]{Life Domain} focuses on the positive energy that helps sustain all life in the multiverse. Clerics who tap into this domain are masters of healing, using that life force to cure many hurts.

Existence itself relies on the positive energy associated with this domain, so a Cleric of almost any religious tradition might choose it. This domain is particularly associated with agricultural deities, gods of healing or endurance, and gods of home and community. Religious orders of healing also seek the magic of this domain.

Light Domain.name: Light Domain
Light Domain.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.TJBxb5HP0PQZbYKY caption=false classes="three right"]

Bring Light to Banish Darkness

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcLightDomai]{Light Domain} emphasizes the divine power to bring about blazing fire and revelation. Clerics who wield this power are enlightened souls infused with radiance and the power of their deities’ discerning vision, charged with chasing away lies and burning away darkness.

The Light Domain is associated with gods of truth, vigilance, beauty, insight, and renewal. Some of these gods are identified with the sun or as charioteers who guide the sun across the sky. Others are sentinels who pierce deception. Some are deities of beauty and artistry who teach that art is a vehicle for the soul’s improvement.

Trickery Domain.name: Trickery Domain
Trickery Domain.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.XofZMGocNyaKDoNg caption=false classes="three right"]

Make Mischief and Challenge Authority

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcTrickeryDo]{Trickery Domain} offers magic of deception, illusion, and stealth. Clerics who wield this magic are a disruptive force in the world, puncturing pride, mocking tyrants, freeing captives, and flouting hollow traditions. They prefer subterfuge and pranks to direct confrontation.

Gods of trickery are mischief-makers and instigators who stand as a constant challenge to the accepted order among both gods and mortals. They embody the forces of change and social upheaval, and they’re patrons of thieves, scoundrels, gamblers, rebels, and liberators. Religious orders that operate in secret, especially those that seek to undermine oppressive governments or hierarchies, also draw on the power of the Trickery Domain.

War Domain.name: War Domain
War Domain.description:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh3ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.YG7dCEzrtTYtdhZz caption=false classes="three right"]

Inspire Valor and Smite Foes

War has many manifestations. It can make heroes of ordinary people. It can be desperate and horrific, with acts of cruelty and cowardice eclipsing instances of excellence and courage. Clerics who tap into the magic of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.classes.Item.phbclcWarDomain0]{War Domain} excel in battle, inspiring others to fight the good fight or offering acts of violence as prayers.

Gods of the War Domain watch over warriors and reward them for their great deeds. They include champions of honor and chivalry as well as gods of destruction and pillage. Other war gods take a more neutral stance, promoting war in all its manifestations and supporting warriors in any circumstance.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.by5JzzXbrTugi96a caption=false]

Adventurers encounter many dangerous monsters and nefarious villains. In those moments, combat often breaks out.

The Order of Combat.name: The Order of Combat
The Order of Combat.text:
A typical combat encounter is a clash between two sides: a flurry of weapon swings, feints, parries, footwork, and spellcasting. The game organizes combat into a cycle of rounds and turns. A round represents about 6 seconds in the game world. During a round, each participant in a battle takes a turn. The order of turns is determined at the beginning of combat when everyone rolls Initiative. Once everyone has taken a turn, the fight continues to the next round if neither side is defeated.

Combat Step by Step

Combat unfolds in these steps:

  1. Establish Positions. The Dungeon Master determines where all the characters and monsters are located. Given the adventurers’ marching order or their stated positions in the room or other location, the DM figures out where the adversaries are—how far away and in what direction.
  2. Roll Initiative. Everyone involved in the combat encounter rolls Initiative, determining the order of combatants’ turns.
  3. Take Turns. Each participant in the battle takes a turn in Initiative order. When everyone involved in the combat has had a turn, the round ends. Repeat this step until the fighting stops.

Initiative.name: Initiative
Initiative.text:
Initiative determines the order of turns during combat. When combat starts, every participant rolls Initiative; they make a Dexterity check that determines their place in the Initiative order. The DM rolls for monsters. For a group of identical creatures, the DM makes a single roll, so each member of the group has the same Initiative.

Surprise. If a combatant is surprised by combat starting, that combatant has &Reference[Disadvantage] on their Initiative roll. For example, if an ambusher starts combat while hidden from a foe who is unaware that combat is starting, that foe is surprised.

Initiative Order. A combatant’s check total is called their Initiative count, or Initiative for short. The DM ranks the combatants, from highest to lowest Initiative. This is the order in which they act during each round. The Initiative order remains the same from round to round.

Ties. If a tie occurs, the DM decides the order among tied monsters, and the players decide the order among tied characters. The DM decides the order if the tie is between a monster and a player character.

Rolling Initiative

When the Dungeon Master adds all combatants to the Combat Tracker they can roll for everyone or allow the player combatants to roll for themselves. The Combat Tracker will automatically place them in order and tracks whose turn it is as the rounds progress.

Ending Combat.name: Ending Combat
Ending Combat.text: Combat ends when one side or the other is defeated, which can mean the creatures are killed or knocked out or have surrendered or fled. Combat can also end when both sides agree to end it.

Movement and Position.name: Movement and Position
Movement and Position.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.wDIv6PADi8Evwao3]

On your turn, you can move a distance equal to your &Reference[Speed] or less. Or you can decide not to move.

Your movement can include @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.a4CjDIEMeSbRaEjA]{climbing}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.zRZl7vdjzjqpazxn]{crawling}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.aaJOlRhI1H6vAxt9]{jumping}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.53c9JMqckHagYYB5]{swimming}. These different modes of movement can be combined with your regular movement, or they can constitute your entire move.

However you’re moving with your @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.NSU7TjeJbJ0vVQaZ]{Speed}, you deduct the distance of each part of your move from it until it is used up or until you are done moving, whichever comes first.

A character’s Speed is determined during character creation. A monster’s Speed is noted in the monster’s stat block. See the rules glossary for more about Speed as well as about special speeds, such as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.xoQXfwUFahXBoiur]{Climb Speed}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.pBcRxpYx5FCVGThO]{Fly Speed}, or @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.wDGTuzKQunNrnkC8]{Swim Speed}.

Difficult Terrain

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.6tqz947qO8vPyxvD inline]

Playing on a Grid

If you play using a square grid and miniatures or other tokens, follow these rules.

Squares. Each square represents 5 feet.

Speed. Rather than moving foot by foot, move square by square on the grid, using your Speed in 5-foot segments. You can translate your Speed into squares by dividing it by 5. For example, a Speed of 30 feet translates into 6 squares. If you use a grid often, consider writing your Speed in squares on your character sheet.

Entering a Square. To enter a square, you must have enough movement left to pay for entering. It costs 1 square of movement to enter an unoccupied square that’s adjacent to your space (orthogonally or diagonally adjacent). A square of Difficult Terrain costs 2 squares to enter. Other effects might make a square cost even more.

Corners. Diagonal movement can’t cross the corner of a wall, a large tree, or another terrain feature that fills its space.

Ranges. To determine the range on a grid between two things—whether creatures or objects—count squares from a square adjacent to one of them and stop counting in the space of the other one. Count by the shortest route.

Breaking Up Your Move

You can break up your move, using some of its movement before and after any action, Bonus Action, or Reaction you take on the same turn. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you could go 10 feet, take an action, and then go 20 feet.

Dropping Prone

Apply Conditions Quickly

Inline Conditions allow you to apply the effect to the currently selected Token. You can also click on the link to open the page and then share it with your players with the "Show Players" link at the top of the window.

On your turn, you can give yourself the &Reference[Prone] condition without using an action or any of your Speed, but you can’t do so if your Speed is 0.

Creature Size

A creature belongs to a size category, which determines the width of the square space the creature occupies on a map, as shown on the Creature Size and Space table. That table lists the sizes from smallest (Tiny) to largest (Gargantuan). A creature’s space is the area that it effectively controls in combat and the area it needs to fight effectively.

A character’s size is determined by species, and a monster’s size is specified in the monster’s stat block.

Moving Around Other Creatures

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.9ZWCknaXCOdhyOrX inline]

Making an Attack.name: Making an Attack
Making an Attack.text:
When you take the &Reference[Attack] action, you make an attack. Some other actions, &Reference[Bonus Action]{Bonus Actions}, and &Reference[Reaction]{Reactions} also let you make an attack. Whether you strike with a Melee weapon, fire a Ranged weapon, or make an attack roll as part of a spell, an attack has the following structure:

  1. Choose a Target. Pick a target within your attack’s range: a creature, an object, or a location.
  2. Determine Modifiers. The DM determines whether the target has &Reference[Cover] and whether you have &Reference[Advantage] or &Reference[Disadvantage] against the target. In addition, spells, special abilities, and other effects can apply penalties or bonuses to your attack roll.
  3. Resolve the Attack. Make the attack roll, as detailed earlier in this chapter. On a hit, you roll damage unless the particular attack has rules that specify otherwise. Some attacks cause special effects in addition to or instead of damage.

Cover.name: Cover
Cover.text:
Walls, trees, creatures, and other obstacles can provide cover, making a target more difficult to harm. As detailed in the Cover table, there are three degrees of cover, each of which gives a different benefit to a target.

A target can benefit from cover only when an attack or other effect originates on the opposite side of the cover. If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies; the degrees aren’t added together. For example, if a target is behind a creature that gives Half Cover and a tree trunk that gives Three-Quarters Cover, the target has Three-Quarters Cover.

Unseen Attackers and Targets

When you make an attack roll against a target you can’t see, you have &reference[Disadvantage] on the roll. This is true whether you’re guessing the target’s location or targeting a creature you can hear but not see. If the target isn’t in the location you targeted, you miss.

When a creature can’t see you, you have &Reference[Advantage] on attack rolls against it.

If you are hidden when you make an attack roll, you give away your location when the attack hits or misses.

Ranged Attacks.name: Ranged Attacks
Ranged Attacks.text:
When you make a ranged attack, you fire a bow, hurl an axe, or otherwise send projectiles to strike a foe at a distance. Many spells also involve making a ranged attack.

Range

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.HjKXuB8ndjcqOds7 inline]

Ranged Attacks in Close Combat

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.qEZvxW0NM7ixSQP5 inline]

Melee Attacks.name: Melee Attacks
Melee Attacks.text:
A melee attack allows you to attack a target within your reach. A melee attack typically uses a handheld weapon or an &Reference[Unarmed Strike]. Many monsters make melee attacks with claws, teeth, or other body parts. A few spells also involve melee attacks.

Reach

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.hgZ5ZN4B3y7tmFlt inline]

Opportunity Attacks

Combatants watch for enemies to drop their guard. If you move heedlessly past your foes, you put yourself in danger by provoking an Opportunity Attack.

Avoiding Opportunity Attacks. You can avoid provoking an Opportunity Attack by taking the Disengage action. You also don’t provoke an Opportunity Attack when you Teleport or when you are moved without using your movement, action, Bonus Action, or Reaction. For example, you don’t provoke an Opportunity Attack if an explosion hurls you out of a foe’s reach or if you fall past an enemy.

Making an Opportunity Attack. You can make an Opportunity Attack when a creature that you can see leaves your reach. To make the attack, take a Reaction to make one melee attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike against that creature. The attack occurs right before it leaves your reach.

Mounted Combat.name: Mounted Combat
Mounted Combat.text:
A willing creature that is at least one size larger than a rider and that has an appropriate anatomy can serve as a mount, using the following rules.

Mounting and Dismounting

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.MFpyvUIdcBpC9kIE inline]

Controlling a Mount

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixDRule.JournalEntryPage.khmR2xFk1NxoQUgZ inline]

Falling Off

If an effect is about to move your mount against its will while you’re on it, you must succeed on a [[/save 10 dex]] saving throw or fall off, landing with the &Reference[Prone] condition in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the mount.

While mounted, you must make the same save if you’re knocked Prone or the mount is.

Underwater Combat.name: Underwater Combat
Underwater Combat.text:
@Embed[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbCh1ArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.scOKuazwklM6F4VX cite=false classes="right two"]

A fight underwater follows these rules.

Impeded Weapons

When making a melee attack roll with a weapon underwater, a creature that lacks a Swim Speed has &Reference[Disadvantage] on the attack roll unless the weapon deals Piercing damage.

A ranged attack roll with a weapon underwater automatically misses a target beyond the weapon’s normal range, and the attack roll has Disadvantage against a target within normal range.

Fire Resistance

Anything underwater has &Reference[Damage Resistance]{Resistance} to Fire damage (explained in @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbDamageAndHeal]{Damage and Healing}).

Overview.name: Resumen
Overview.text:
Muchos efectos imponen un estado que altera temporalmente las capacidades de una criatura. Los siguientes estados se definen en el glosario:

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.uDogReMO6QtH6NDw]{Blinded}
  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.vLAsIUa0FhZNsyLk]{Charmed}

  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.content.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.jSQtPgNm0i4f3Qi3]{Exhaustion}
